author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Authorities in Khartoum are exhuming bodies hastily buried during Sudan’s two-year conflict.
Thousands have been recovered since the army regained control earlier this year, with many more still in unconventional sites like schools and homes.
Residents say intense fighting and RSF checkpoints forced them to bury the dead nearby.
Many bodies show signs of decomposition, victims of crossfire, starvation, or lack of healthcare.
So far, 15,000 bodies have been collected, with an equal number likely remaining.
Forensic experts are few, and limited funding complicates the process of proper reburial.
Authorities warn exhumations and cemetery transfers will take weeks amid ongoing challenges.

Al Jazeera’s Hiba Morgan reports from Khartoum.

title: Sudan war: Thousands of bodies exhumed in Khartoum as authorities work to restore capital

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Syria’s Sednaya prison, once whispered about in fear, symbolised silence, disappearance and state terror.
Two former detainees have returned a year after the Assad regime’s fall to walk through the cells that shaped their lives.
They recount inhumane treatment, humiliation, and executions designed to erase both bodies and identities.
Cell blocks sealed from the outside world left prisoners isolated from families, sunlight and human contact.
For years, human rights groups documented Sednaya as central to Assad’s machinery of repression.
Returning is a step for the men to reclaim their stories and confront the trauma they endured.
For Syria, facing the truth about Sednaya is seen as vital for justice and rebuilding the nation.

Al Jazeera’s Resul Serdar reports from Damascus.

title: Syria’s Sednaya prison: Former detainees recount horrors one year after Assad’s fall

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The Fourth Geneva Convention, adopted in 1949, sets out to protect civilians during armed conflicts, prohibiting murder, torture, sexual violence, forced displacement, and ensuring access to food, healthcare, and humanitarian aid.
Pierre Krahenbuhl, Director General of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), told Al Jazeera that conditions in Gaza remain “treacherous” for humanitarian teams. He warned that permissive interpretations of international humanitarian law are being used to justify attacks on civilians and hospitals, with grievous violations occurring daily. Krahenbuhl stressed that the ceasefire must hold and highlighted the painstaking efforts of the ICRC to return hostages to their families, repatriate deceased individuals, and support released Palestinian prisoners. He emphasised the urgent need for increased humanitarian aid, including rehabilitation of health facilities, restoration of water systems, and medical support across Gaza. Krahenbuhl also undersc
title: ICRC director warns world must act to protect civilians in Gaza

Some of the victims remain unidentified. Civil defense teams are moving them to cemeteries to give them a proper final resting place.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is asking for a pardon over a range of corruption charges laid against him after repeatedly telling Israeli journalists that he would clear his name in court.

The prime minister has long described the case against him as a witch-hunt led by the media and the judiciary. If he succeeds in sidestepping the courts, Israeli journalists and judges will wonder what he might have in store for them.

Contributors:
Daniel Levy – President, US/Middle East Project
Dana Mills – Writer, Local Call & +972 Magazine
Jonathan Ofir – Writer, Mondoweiss
Dan Perry – Author, "Ask Questions Later" Substack

On our radar:

This week, former United States Secretary of State Hillary Clinton insisted Israel’s PR problems have more to do with TikTok than with the genocide Israeli forces have inflicted on Gaza. Ryan Kohls looks at a persistent myth still making the rounds in American political circles.

The phenomenon of Kim Ou-Joon

Kim Ou-Joon is part journalist, part
title: #SorryNotSorry Netanyahu demands a pardon | The Listening Post

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Hamas’s Qassam Brigade and the Red Cross are searching for the remains of the final Israeli captive, police officer Ran Gvili, in Gaza’s al-Zaitoun neighbourhood. 
The operation is taking place within the “Yellow Line”, still under Israeli control, with Egyptian equipment assisting the effort. 
Israel has permitted the search to speed up the recovery process, as retrieving this last body is essential for triggering the second phase of the ceasefire agreement. 
The Red Cross says it is acting as a neutral intermediary but warns that the extensive destruction in the area is making the search extremely challenging.

Al Jazeera’s Ibrahim al-Khalili reports from Gaza City.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Southeast Asia is facing one of its worst storm seasons on record.
Thousands of people have died or are missing across Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Thailand and Sri Lanka -
And another storm is currently forming in the Philippine Sea.
Central Vietnam saw the second-highest known total of 24-hour rainfall this year - and while governments are promising to rebuild, 
it's not clear how they can afford to do so every year as the storm seasons get worse. 
At the same time, the UN announced that it's slashed its 2026 budget for response to war and natural disasters by half.
These countries are increasingly on their own - left to try and put cities and lives back together, storm after storm.
So, how is this changing lives and livelihoods? 
And what does the future of flood recovery look like across Southeast Asia?

Presenter: Dareen Abughaida

Guests: 

Alexandre Borde - Environmental Economist and CEO of Cibola Partners. 

Sehr Raheja - Programme Officer for the Climate Change Progr
title: Can Southeast Asia cope with record-breaking storms? | Inside Story

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Syrian President Ahmad al-Sharaa marked one year since the fall of al-Assad regime, praising those who fought, suffered, and rebuilt hope. 
He framed the uprising as a historic liberation that restored Syria’s dignity after decades of tyranny. He portrayed Damascus as the cradle of civilisation, now reclaiming its place after years of darkness. The President condemned the former regime for corruption, oppression, and dividing society through fear. He pledged a new era of justice, accountability, and national unity, with economic reforms and renewed international partnerships. He emphasised raising living standards, restoring state institutions, and committing to transitional justice for victims and the missing. Concluding, he urged Syrians to turn victory into responsibility through hard work to build a strong, leading nation.

title: One year after al-Assad’s fall, is a new Syria emerging? | The Take

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Thirty years after the Bosnian war, vast areas of the country remain contaminated with landmines, leaving thousands of people living with persistent danger. 
Bosnia remains one of Europe’s most mine-affected regions, and progress has slowed further since the withdrawal of the last foreign humanitarian demining teams earlier this year, due to shifting global crises. 
Their departure has stalled clearance efforts and deepened fears among communities who continue to find mines in forests, fields and near their homes. 
Local de-miners say they lack the resources to address the scale of the problem, leaving residents feeling increasingly unsafe. 

Al Jazeera’s Arduana Pribinja reports from Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Thailand has launched air attacks along its disputed border with Cambodia as the two neighbours trade blame for renewed fighting.
The clashes have killed at least one Thai soldier and four Cambodian civilians, with tens of thousands forced from their homes.
Thailand says military action against Cambodia will continue until Thailand’s sovereignty and territorial integrity are secured.
The reignition of fighting along the disputed Thai-Cambodian border has led to a new wave of displacement as tens of thousands of people fled their areas.
According to Thailand’s army, more than 50,000 people have left areas near the border for shelters.
In Cambodia, meanwhile, Information Minister Neth Pheaktra said that tens of thousands of residents had been displaced from several villages near the border.
Both countries have accused each other of breaching a ceasefire agreement brokered by Malaysia, and China and the US. 

Al Jazeera’s Bernard Smith reports. 

Subscribe to our channel: http://bit.ly/A
title: Thailand–Cambodia tensions: Thousands flee as border clashes reignite

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
When the al-Assad regime falls, Ammar, a Syrian lawyer and former Sednaya prison detainee, is determined to uncover the truth about Syria’s missing. Haunted by the disappeared and his own imprisonment, he searches for answers in the ruins of Sednaya prison.

Among classified documents, he discovers records of enforced disappearances and deaths, exposing the regime’s brutality. With each case, Ammar pursues justice and closure, offering families a chance to grieve and heal.

His search is about more than closure - it provides a fragile hope and a path towards reconciliation and justice in a fractured Syria.

#aljazeeraenglish #syria #basharalassad #sednaya #prison #humanrights #documentary
title: Syria’s Prison of Secrets: The search for Sednaya’s missing | Witness Documentary

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
This year saw devastating climate impacts across the Global South, from catastrophic floods in Bangladesh to unprecedented destruction in the Amazon and intensifying heat across Africa. Activists argue that the communities most affected still have little real influence over global climate decisions, even as governments and corporations claim to lead the fight. The Stream speaks with climate organisers demanding accountability.

Presenter: Stefanie Dekker

Guests:
Emmanuella Direen Kwofie - Climate advocate and lawyer
Roxy Mathew Koll - Climate scientist
Xananine Calvillo Ramirez - Climate and food justice activist

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Syria has seen new social media platforms, student movements and cultural collectives emerge as spaces for debate and reform.
Political conversations once whispered in private are now openly discussed.
These changes mark a rare opening in public life after years of repression.
But questions persist over whether such freedoms can withstand entrenched power structures.
New political pressures are also casting uncertainty over the future of these forums.
A year after the fall of the Assad regime, the landscape remains fluid and fragile.

Al Jazeera’s Osama Bin Javaid reports from Aleppo on how different regions are navigating this transition.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The Assad family ruled Syria for more than 50 years.
It took less than two weeks for the regime to fall.

On November the 27th last year, Syrian rebels launched a major offensive in western Aleppo against Assad’s forces. 
It was the first significant conflict between the two sides in years.

Three days later, the rebels seized Aleppo.
It was the first time the fighters had set foot in the city since 2016, when they were forced out by government forces.

The fighters extended their offensive into Hama, giving them control of a strategic central city they’d never held before.
By December the 6th, opposition forces had captured most of the southern region of Daraa – the birthplace of the uprising in 2011.

In their lightning advance, the fighters took over the city of Homs, cutting off government forces from their coastal strongholds.

In the early hours of December the 8th, they entered the capital Damascus, facing very little resistance from government forces. 

The leader of the main
title: How the offensive on Aleppo ended Assad’s rule in Syria

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Syria is marking a year since the collapse of the Assad regime.
A dynastic rule that survived five decades, including uprisings and civil wars, fell in a matter of days. 

A lightning assault by fighters late last year resulted in the takeover of the capital Damascus. 
It surprised everyone, including the fighters themselves.

The collapse brought relief to many Syrians - the first they had felt in many years, since Bashar’s father, Hafez al-Assad, seized power in 1971. 

In 2011, antigovernment protests swept across the country during the Arab Spring.
Syrian forces launched a brutal crackdown and the uprising escalated into a full-scale civil war.

For more than a decade, the Assad regime committed atrocities, erasing entire neighbourhoods with barrel bombs and deploying chemical weapons against civilians.
Hundreds of thousands of people were killed. Around 100,000 others went missing

Many of Assad's opponents were locked up in prisons like Sednaya.
When inmates were freed, many eme
title: Syria marks one year since fall of Bashar al-Assad's regime

description:
Video shows crowds in Gaza celebrating after Palestine qualified for the Arab Cup quarter-finals. Palestinians waved flags, chanted songs and gathered around screens in a rare moment of joy amid the ongoing devastation.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The Sudanese Doctors Network has condemned what it calls the use of mass rape by the Rapid Support Forces, against women fleeing el-Fasher.
The network is calling on countries to investigate the violations. It says it's documented 19 cases so far. 
On Friday, officials in the South Kordofan state said the paramilitary group killed at least 80 people in a drone attack on a preschool. 
The war between Sudan's army and the RSF has caused what the UN describes as the world's largest humanitarian crisis. 

Mohammed Elsheikh, a spokesperson for the Sudan Doctors Network, told Al Jazeera that he was “100 percent sure” that sexual violence committed by RSF fighters is far more widespread than reported.

title: Sudan group condemns RSF using rape as weapon of war on women fleeing el-Fasher

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Thailand's army says it's launched air strikes after one of its soldiers was killed in fighting along its disputed border with Cambodia.
Both sides accuse each other of breaking a US-backed ceasefire that stopped fighting earlier this year.
Residents are fleeing border areas, as tension escalates.
Officials in Cambodia say three civilians were severely injured in the clashes.
In Thailand, the military says more than 385,000 civilians across four districts are being evacuated.

Thailand says seven of its troops were wounded when its forces came under fire from Cambodian forces in the Chong Bok area.
Cambodia's defence ministry accused Thailand of launching an attack on two border provinces, saying its forces did not retaliate.

Thitinan Pongsudhirak is a professor of political science at Chulalongkorn University. He explains what's at stake for both countries.

title: Thailand launches air strikes along Cambodia border as renewed fighting breaks out

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Victims of political violence that shook Senegal for three years until 2024 gathered on Sunday for what the government calls a “Martyrs and Victims Day.”
The meeting, led by Prime Minister Ousmane Sonko, aimed to address compensation, psychological support, and justice for those affected.

Al Jazeera’s Nicolas Haque reports from Dakar, Senegal.
